sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Handwritten postcard from Harden to Schenker; undated; postmarked June 14, 1894
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: Harden says he will look over an article by Schenker soon; he wonders whether Brahms or Rosenthal will contribute anything on Bülow to Die Zukunft; and he encourages Schenker to send him more articles in the future.
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: Harden, Maximilian; Schenker, Heinrich; Brahms; Rubinstein, Anton; Rosenthal, Moriz

tei:p.tei:hi: Handwritten postcard from Harden to Schenker, undated; postmarked June 14, 1894

tei:transcription.tei:p: {recto} [preprinted form with handwritten address information] Deutsche Reichspost Postkarte
An [/] Herrn Dr. H. Schenker in Kautzen (Nieder-Oesterreich) Wohnung [intentionally left blank]

ich will mich bemühen, den Rubinstein This became the article “Anton Rubinstein,” which appeared in Die Zukunft on August 18, 1894, and is reprinted in Hellmut Federhofer, Heinrich Schenker als Essayist und Kritiker (Hildesheim: Georg Olms Verlag, 1990), pp. 82–84. Click on Rubinstein. bald zu fassen. Mit Brahms und Rosenthal Click on Moriz Rosenthal, student of Karol Mikuli (of whom Schenker had been a pupil, too), and authentic interpreter of Chopin. Harden is hoping that either Brahms or Rosenthal or both will contribute something on Bülow to Die Zukunft, and he is using Schenker as a go-between. See OJ 11/42, 14. wirds wohl nichts werden?
Wenn Sie später wieder Etwas senden, wirds mich immer freuen.
Mit herzlichem Gruß Ihr erg. [signed:] Harden

tei:p.tei:hi: Handwritten postcard from Harden to Schenker, undated; postmarked June 14, 1894

tei:translation.tei:p: {recto} [preprinted form with handwritten address information] German Imperial Post Postcard
To Dr. H. Schenker in Kautzen (Lower Austria) Address [intentionally left blank]
I will try to take up the Rubinstein soon. Probably nothing will happen with Brahms and Rosenthal?
I will always be happy if you send me something else later.
